Must watch but be aware of the time this movie was made, why it was made etc. it might seem slow but there's a deeper meaning than the visuals you see.

My father told me about it in the '60s and I finally saw it in the late '80s. I still see Bruno weeping softly while his totally devastated father is being humiliated. The movie is unforgettable and if you don't feel for Bruno or his father, you aren't human. It is perhaps the best ever performance of a child actor. It remains one of the best movies I have ever seen.

This is the first Italian movie I had ever seen, and I only hope that they get better.What a marvelous film.   With such a simple theme, I thought that the movie would be more boring and slow moving.   However I was very enchanted.I think that it is wonderful that DeSica did not use professional actors in this movie.   To follows this man's journey in finding his bicycle is really to follow his journey to find his soul.   It's not just about the bike. It's about him trying to find his place in society in post WWII Europe. He wants to be a man and take care of his family.   He is trying to set an example for his young son.   In the end he does indeed set and example, however it is not the one that he had intended.

MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS: Vittorio de Sica's The Bicycle Thief uses several formal film elements to illustrate the depressed economy of the post-war Italy in which the film takes place.  One element that really struck me was the mis-en-scéne in the film.  The most striking of which, was the pile of bags of linens.  When Antonio and his wife, Maria, were forced to pawn their linens to afford the bicycle, the man in the back that had to put away the linens had to climb, what seemed to be stories of bundles of linens. Seeing how many people had to pawn their bed sheets really affected me and proved to what an impoverished state this family/town was in.  Another aspect of the mis-en-scéne that was effective were the costumes, especially Antonio's frayed and worn jacket.  This was really apparent in the restaurant scene when Antonio took his son Bruno out to eat.  They were the only ones in the restaurant in such disheveled clothing.  Bruno kept catching dirty looks from a well dressed little boy sitting at another table because Bruno was wearing his torn up jacket and shorts. In the beginning of the film a large group of men stood outside waiting to hear news of jobs that were available to them.  All the men looked poverty-stricken and some were hostile.  All of those unemployed men had to stand outside waiting to hear about `good government jobs', and for many, only to be denied. The Bicycle Thief makes for a great example of neo-realism in Italy in part because of all these great examples of mis-en-scene depicting the depressed economy of Italy.

reviews.review_title: It’s the ending of the movie which really touches your heart, and makes it a masterpiece which it is today.
reviews.content: Ladri di biciclette, also known as Bicycle Thief, is directed by Vittorio De Sica, and produced by Giuseppe Amato. Filmed in 1948 in Italy, Bicycle Thieves is a neo-realistic film which deals with the poor economic conditions of Italy in the Post World War II era. The film stars Lamberto Maggiorani in the lead role of Antonio Ricci, and Enzo Staiola as Bruno Ricci, the son of Antonia Ricci. In the supporting cast, Lianella Carell plays the role Maria Ricci, the wife of Antonio Ricci.Bicycle Thief, very articulately depicts the conditions of the poor people in Italy after the World War II. Poverty, crimes, unemployment, and depression were the main issues during that period. Although, hard to relate for me with it, this cinema somewhat reminds me of the 70’s era of Bollywood in which poverty, unemployment, crimes were also the main issues. Also, the frustrations of the protagonist to overcome all these issues, and to break his morals and take the wrong way in order to fight with these issues, are similar between these two cinemas.The most debatable point in the movie is the stealing of bicycle by Antonio. Is it right to commit crime of any level when you are in trouble? Is it ethical to put someone else in trouble in order to get rid of yours? These are some questions which Bicycle Thief raises. In my opinion, it’s not right to commit a crime like stealing etc. to get some money. No matter how difficult your conditions are, taking the path of crime is always wrong. I maybe sound philosophical but I believe in “What Goes Around Comes Around”. If you’ve done something wrong today, intentionally, you’ve to bear the consequences later or as many people call it, Karma.The ending of the movie supports my point; after stealing the bicycle he’s caught by the public and humiliated in front of his own son. I don’t think there is any bigger insult than that for a man i.e. getting caught stealing something in front of your son.And he clearly knows it and that’s why he asks his son to wait somewhere else before stealing the bike. He didn’t want him to about it. He didn’t want to lose his respect.“Bicycle Thief” is a great learning experience, both in terms of film making and how to live life in general. I think the one of the strongest points of this film is its unpredictability. The director creates the situations such that you start to think that he’ll get the bicycle back but you are always proved wrong. For example; when Antonio and his friends go to cycle market to find his bicycle, they meet a guy who is painting a bicycle and they think that he is a thief and it is his bicycle. And when that guy refuses to show it to them, they call the police. And just when you think they have found it, it turns out that guy is telling the truth.Also, the situation where Antonio runs after the thief gives you an idea that he’ll find the bicycle but you’re mistaken again. These small things create the suspense which was required in this cinema. The most surprising element of the movie is the acting and that’s because Lamberto Maggiorani was not a trained actor at that time and he used to work in a factory. And, Enzo Staiola was only seven when he was cast for this role. To see such powerful performances from both the leads coming from non-movie backgrounds is mind blowing.On the whole, I absolutely loved this movie. It’s a great piece of cinema and I’m not surprised that it’s being considered as the best neo-realistic film ever.Screen play of the movie is top notch and direction is superb. Despite being a very old film, I enjoyed it a lot. It has the perfect blend of commercial and meaningful cinema. It’s the ending of the movie which really touches your heart, and makes it a masterpiece which it is today.

This film implicates the fact that good luck does not last forever and bad luck is always right around the corner.  This film is about a man named Antonio who finally gets a job by hanging posters.  In order to do this job, he has to use a bicycle to get around town in which he has one but has to buy it out of storage.  On the first day of his job, somebody steals the bicycle and Antonio is unable to catch the thief because no one helps him. The next day Antonio and his son go looking for the bike only to run into many obstacles along the way.  The two are able to find the thief of the bicycle, but are unable to do anything about it because there were no witnesses and no proof.  Antonio is so depressed that he decides to steal someone's bicycle but gets caught in front of his own son. The narrative techniques are much different then what you would see in many other films.  Throughout the film, there are many instances that make the audience believe that Antonio is going to get his bicycle back and the family is going to live happily ever after.  This doesn't actually happen though.  Antonio gets one chance after another but always falls short and it makes one believe that he has to get the bike back some how.  The film shows all these bicycles running around and you just think to yourself that one of them is going to be his.  The film kind of keeps you in suspense of how the film is actually going to turn out.  One thing that I found interesting about how this film was done was when Antonio's bicycle was stolen and later when he almost caught the thief, no one helped him.  When Antonio decided to steal a bicycle though about 10 people tried to stop him and succeeded. The film is telling the audience that just because one person gets away with something, doesn't mean that everybody will.

This is one of the most touching and emotionally attaching movies of all time, a great example of post war Italian cinema, a triumph.After I first saw it I was completely blown away. I re-watched it four times the following week, because never before had a movie touched me so deeply and profoundly – and I must admit that I wept tears of grief and admiration. To me everything in this film is perfect – the performances are splendid and very true to life and the story is simple but wonderful.In the center of the movie is a story about Antonio Ricci – a men living in poor Rome neighborhood, who acquires a bicycle to get a job posting film posters in the city, to support his family. The bike gets stolen soon afterwards, so he goes looking for it across Rome with the help of his son and friends.Ricci's character is greatly portrayed by an unprofessional actor Lamberto Maggiorani, who portrays the character with admirable emotion and sincerity. The performances and also the way the movie is shot, make it stand above other films of the period.I would recommend this movie to anyone, seeing it is an unforgettable experience and possibly even a life changing one.

I saw this movie some days ago, I expected it to be sad; and it definitely lived up to my expectations. I am no movie expert but I saw it because I have read it's one of the greatest films ever. I really don't get the feeling of what it is that makes it great, but I'd like to say that say that despite being sad it's not bitter, and that what impressed me most about it was the boy's performance. These two points remain in me, and maybe that is where the power and magic of this movie resides: what could be deemed by an ordinary mind like mine an ordinary film, turns out to leave an profound mark in your mind. It surprised me too to see that the film was made just three years after WW II was over and how a now rich country could once be so poor and needy and today be at the same level countries that were in better shape then.

Contains Spoiler Vittorio de Sica's `The Bicycle Thief' is an Italian neo-realism film that is about a family during the great depression.  Antonio Ricci (the father) finds a chance to work at a good city job pasting up postures around the town.  At this time the community would do anything to find employment of this kind.  Because they are short on money his wife sells bed sheets to receive money for a bike that he needs in order to keep his new job.  On his first day of his job his new bike that he just got gets stolen and he tries to do everything to track down the thief.  With a chance to try and get his family out of poverty he takes his son Bruno and some friends and head out into the city to try and keep his family an opportunity to get wealthy. With many frustrating events that occur through out the day Antonio decides to steal a bike himself and later getting himself caught and thrown in jail.One important factor in this movie is how the thoughts in Antonio's mind never get brought out to us throughout the movie but are shown to us through his facial expressions and the way he presents his body and emotions. Another factor that is important in the movie is how there are no staged settings present.  This movie uses real life settings and backgrounds that help give a better feeling or realism and makes the situations more effective to the eyes.  Finally the ending is also important.  After the prison feels sorry for Antonio and decides that he has gone through enough they let him out and the movie just ends abruptly with Antonio and his son Bruno taking a walk back through the town.  The movies uses this strategy to once again give a remembrance of the time its set in and also leaves the audience with something to unravel.

Simply the best film ever made. In the midst of a new era of film making it still has its post-war message to give us, a message of worthiness and human nobility, and visions of how to reach a better future.

SPOILER******BE AWARE SPOILERLadri di Biciclette is a film that tells people that hope and love can only go so far in the world.  In this film the main character gets a job when all other people could not get one, and gives his heart to keep it.  However, in the end it does him no good.  His family worked so hard to keep themselves living and going in the cruel and poor world of Rome, but a thief had to change all of that.  Through the course of the film the man's desperation builds and builds feeling that he is going to lose his new job and his new life all because of a thief.  The entire film is meant to make the audience feel remorse for this man and what is happening to him.  I felt remorse before he even lost his bike, because I knew it was going to happen.  The makers of this film want people to realize that you need to make sure things are going to go well for you, not hope and pray they will.  Going to a psychic as in the film did no good for their situation.  People rely on hope to much, and those people are the ones that get no where fast.  Near the end of the film the man is tired of looking for his bike and wants to get some food for himself and his son.  The bond between his son and him is so enormous.  At times it seems that the kid is more of an adult then the father.  The father always scared, or nervous and the kid always voicing his opinion; the film not just about the bicycle I believe it is also about him and his son.  Showing that even in times of desperation your family can try help you out even if that help is hopeless as in this case.  A big political issue is that even though he found the person who took his bike, and he knew it was him he could do nothing.  Politics today and back then said you need to have proof of the act, and since the man had no proof he could not do anything.  If he did, and they found this kid to be innocent of the crime the man could have been the one in jail and not the kid.  Politics are a very important part of how this world works; we need them to maintain order. However, in this case it seems that politics and law made more crime and less justice than it is suppose to.  Seeing this guy walk away from the group of thugs knowing that there was no more hope at all could have made anyone feel bad.  The big social issue is forgiveness.  The reason is that the man was so desperate he went to steal a bike himself.  However, for him he got caught and was going to be sent to jail, but the man he stole it from let him go because he saw this man's son and felt he had enough problems. Forgiveness is a very important part of everyone's life, because without it you will be a very sad person.  This film overall was very depressing, but a good example of how hope can not solve everything.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever
reviews.content: After all these great review there is little for me to add. I saw this movie in 1988, and it struck me very deeply. To this day, 20 years later, I remember most details vividly. Spoiler The Bicycle Thief is a classic example of Italian Neorealism.  As of many neorealistic films that display some sort of personal struggle, this one displays a powerful message of society and Europe's post-war struggle. The film portrayals a young man, Ricci, and his son, Bruno, as they search for a stolen bicycle during a time of depression in Italy.  From the beginning to the end, the film centers on the dreary aspect of a desperate man's struggle to survive. The film displays the message of society's struggles and of Ricci's hard life throughout the entire film.  It expresses this by being in black and white.  This view gives a distant aspect to every scene and relays the message that what is scene is all there is that there is no deeper meaning to anything, the meaning that all there is this struggle to work.  From its scenes of angry workers debating over solutions to the economy to the police and church turning down Ricci's pleads for help displays the neorealistic message of society and its struggle at this time.  The mise en scene of the film expresses the message of Europe's post-war struggles as well.  From its long shots to its panning of the streets and building to the character's clothing and movements gives one the impression of Italy.  Through this mise in scene realistic view, the feeling of Italy as it was at the time, and with that impression the people's struggles are found to be believable.Lastly, the final scene of Ricci becoming so desperate that he decides to steal a bicycle is the best example of the films message of society. Ricci's attempt to steal the bicycle in front of his son Bruno finally displayed the measures that Ricci would take.  This is foreseen by his increased desperation throughout the course of the film.  In the scene the panning shots of him pacing and close-up shots of his face give away the fact that he is about to steal the bicycle and destroy his son's exaggerated heroic view of his father.  This event finally makes Bruno realize the reality of the situation and his father's disposition and struggle in this society.

The movie ends and I sit in awe.  This spectacular film will grace your top 10 list, or at least rank amongst the best foreign language films.As for the controversy over the title (which I did not know until afterwards), I love that the English title is singular.  I exclaimed afterwards that I thought it was the best title given to a movie.  Since we know from the title that a bicycle will be stolen, the camera and story teases and tricks the viewer (that viewer being me).  I loved it.A must see for any movie buff(s).

Tukta Phetasa March 24, 2014 Art 102: Ávalos Bicycle ThievesA roller-coaster ride of emotion Bicycle Thieves captures your undivided attention with its brutally honest take on Post War Italy. The Italian Neorealism was a movement in the film industry that generally characterized the daily lives of the lower class. This included showing the whole truth of living in poverty, oppression, injustice, and desperation in that time. Bicycle Thieves highlights the desperation in the Italian neorealist movement by showcasing the desperation a man faces trying to support his family. This story surrounds an inanimate object to draw forth your emotions. Not because of what the object is physically, but what it symbolizes as whole. The bicycle itself symbolizes salvation for a family in need because without this bike he cannot do his job and without his job he cannot provide for his family. This movie features Lamberto Maggiorani, who is not a professional actor he plays Ricci a man that lands a job hanging movie posters. This job requires that he must have a bicycle but Ricci has pawned it off to get money to pay for food. He knows that everyone around him is desperate to find a job so he lies and says he will have the bicycle by the start of work. He tells his wife that he finally finds a job but he unfortunately can't accept it. He is sad because he feels as if he cannot catch a break because every opportunity is ridden with false hope. His wife gives him the sheets to pawn off and trade it in for the bicycle.There was a scene where we were falsely misled into thinking the bike was going to be stolen when he takes his wife to a psychics' house so she could pay her for her husbands good fortune. Ricci doesn't know what she is going to do so he gets curious and follows her up even though she tells him to stay put. He tells someone to watch his bike as he goes to see what his wife is up to. Everyone thinks that this would be the moment that his bike would be stolen so you watch with a bad feeling in your gut. He then stops his wife from wasting money on the psychic by saying that he didn't get the job because she came to see him. He reports for work and someone teaches him how to paste the posters and as he is going on his own and is posting his first poster someone takes off with his bike. This seemed to be a group effort as someone rides off with his bike and someone else steers him into the wrong direction. There aren't as many people who were willing to help him capture the thief. The police weren't much help either after he goes to report the stolen bike. He then goes to his friends and they and his son Bruno go searching all over Rome trying to find his bike. Eventually his friends give up hope leaving him and his son to continue the search. Ricci gets desperate as he goes on a manhunt with his son. He starts accusing everyone and reveals that everyone is in the same boat as him. They are all dealing with poverty and despair as everywhere shares the same everyday struggles to find a job and support their family.Speaking of family, his son Bruno steals the show because he pulls emotions from you that you wouldn't otherwise get from just watching the father desperately search for a bike. Bruno showcases his fathers' insufficiency to provide for his family as he ignores his son. One scene he gets so frustrated and fed up that he slaps Bruno, as horror rushes through Bruno's face he walks way from his father. Then a huge crowd gathers as someone is yelling about a boy drowning in the water. Ricci rushes to the water petrified and filled with regret as he discovers that the boy was not Bruno. After this sigh of relief he still doesn't apologize or rejoice that his son is alive. In another scene we see that he is almost hit by a car but his father doesn't seem to care as he has an expressionless walk contemplating revenge. The cycle is about to repeat itself as Ricci tries to steal another mans bicycle but in his desperation and unsuccessful attempt at trying to even the odds. He gets caught and this time there are tons of people who try to stop him, as his boy Bruno watches in shock of what his father had just done. In the final scene the man reluctantly lets him go instead of putting him in jail as he sees Bruno's frightened and sadden look. In the end he doesn't get resolution but instead he gets humiliation, his son was his savior and Ricci loses all his self-respect. De Sica truly captures real emotions by captivating the audience with real settings and a nonprofessional cast. He makes it pretty predictable by making it extremely believable and not too far-fetched to understand. Ricci's dry emotions really capture his distress and humiliation.

Great job with idea it is make you think aout your life that you life and search about your bicycle that you fear to lost at the same side you learn to take care to dont waste your hope with doing mistakes .

In the movie, "The Bicycle Thieves" we are able to see the meaning of Ne-realism at it's best. Neorealism defined as a style of filming prominent in Italy after World War II, characterized by a concern for social issues and often shot on location with untrained actors. This film seems really "real" to the viewers and we are able to connect with Antonio. This film was filmed in the streets because after World War II, studios had been destroyed. In the film we are able to see Antonio's struggle to better himself to help support his family. It is social issue we can all relate to. It's a story of an illusion that was shattered when his bike was stolen from him. A major emphasis put on the bike throughout the film as the search to locate the stolen bike in the streets of Rome begins. Not an easy task but to Antonio this bike is so important; it represents a job, a home, food, and family. It's an illusion that Antonio has that he's tempted to steal a bicycle himself due to his loss of hope. Getting the bike back is all that is Antonio's mind. In the film, "Bicycle Thieves", we are able to see the cycle of theft and poverty as Antonio makes the ultimate decision to gain his stolen bicycle by doing the same and stealing another man's bicycle in his desire to reach this illusion that represents a better life for him and his family.The bicycle in this film is of high importance; it symbolizes the working class status as the important motive, presenting a Ne-realistic Italian society after World War II. The film also contains a logic that shows how contradictory and disappointing life can be. Antonio is offered a job requiring a bicycle. Not having one, his wife Maria pawns some household items in order to acquire the needed transportation. Then on his first day of work, the bike is devastatingly stolen. He needs a job because he has no money, but to get a job he needs a bicycle, a bicycle costs money, which he surely can't afford. This goes to show part of the cycle of theft and poverty with the last scene of the film to completely demonstrate the cycle. In the opening scene we are able to sense the pain of neglect as we see a crowd of unemployed men rush forward as the officer is announcing the name of the lucky man. After two years of being unemployed, Ricci is finally offered a job as poster hanger and we're able to see the happiness it's brought him. As Ricci stands out, the camera allows us to have a view of the crowd. Instead of directly shooting at people's faces, the camera portrays the back of their heads. Then as the camera turning around, we finally see a group of young men waiting for the moment when the officer calls their names. De Sica uses the dehumanized images to allude and to show what the government sees these people (Doubon.com). As the viewers, we see them as young muscular Italians; however, for the government, they are just a group of livestock waiting for the meaningless jobs.The scene I have chosen to analyze is the scene where the father steals a bike from a side street and gets chased by a crowd of people. We are able to see the humiliation this creates for both his son and him. Antonio does not carry those characteristic traits to go out and steal from people. The situation he was in is what led him to the decision to steal the bike of another person. It might not have been the right thing to do but he had lost all hope. Getting another person back seemed to be he's only chance he had of getting back to his job after he tried everything. He tried to do everything he could in order to get it back, searched everywhere and even when he had the robber in front of him the police couldn't do anything. To me the above scene is the most dramatic and intense part of the film. We are able to see an emotionally erratic son chase after his father because he sees people grabbing him and shouting at him. Even though, these are untrained actors, it is incredible to see how well they display emotions. We feel a connection with the little boy when see the worried expression painted across his face and the tears of sadness. We can't help to feel sorry for both of them because we know the circumstances he made that action to steal a bike. Poverty was a key driver to the actions of Antonio and we are able to see it in the film and how it plays an important role in it. We are able to see a city in ruins with people in ripped and dirty clothes which helps reinforce the idea of poverty in Italy at the time. This explains the reason behind Antonio's desperation to get his job back by locating his stolen bike. Even though, the bicycle is the main focus throughout the film, poverty is what lies behind it. If he was not poor, the bike would mean nothing to him. But this bike symbolizes a job that he desperately needs during this hard times. We are able to see poverty when his wife goes and sells their bed sheets to obtain the bicycle in order to attend his first day of work The film succeeds in creating empathy for Antonio's dejected state so that his ultimate act becomes an understandable and painful reaction. It supplies one possible answer to the question: What makes a thief?

It is worthing watching this film just to look at Rome. Then add a magnificent script, superb acting, harsh reality, and you have one of the greatest films of all time. DeSica did a fine job portraying the misery and poverty of post WWII Italy. One could argue that it is Bruno, the young boy, who is in fact the driving force behind this film. It is his balanced performance, displaying both the youthful innocence of boy and the matureness that can forced upon youth when on faced with the responsibility of taking part in the family's survival, that really make this film special. A classic, definitely worth buying from the Criterion Collection.
The beginning of neo-realism. Modern filmmaking and acting hails back to this film.

reviews.review_title: We are all human, corrupt, proud, and imperfect!
reviews.content: This film is gritty and insightful into the very core of human nature. It showcases the human struggle, honestly contemplated for good and ill.As much as we want to think an absolute morality exists, Bicycle Thieves illustrates just how harrowing real life challenges can be, full of trade offs, success and failure intertwined into each life set against an imperfect society.I love the pawn shop scenes where wealth is locked away in storage away from people who can use it.And I love the church lock-in scene, where the poor are helped if they submit to imprisoned moral spoon-feeding.This film rages quietly against uncaring capitalism and fascist religious proselytizing, and highlights just how powerful the existential challenge is for a human with a good heart....sometimes the good heart fails, and that is just how reality is sometimes. Utter sadness.

Similar to Cinema Paradiso, this movie tells you about another time and place you never knew existed. I liked how it ended and that it was about something simple, a bike, but about so much more, poverty, crime, morality, love, self esteem.

Filmmakers should learn from Bicycle Thief. Learn what can be achieved economically without ridiculous budgets. Tens of millions of dollars were not necessary to create what is one of the best films in history.What a beautiful film it is! The innocence of these characters even with their faults due to their desperation after their livelihood is shot with the loss of their bicycle. This is a human story about the human struggle as father and son walk all over the city to find their stolen bicycle. As simple as the film is, it's highly emotional, particularly the final, famous scene. My favourite moment was in the restaurant as the son is wary not to spoil his father's budget, and the father is too concerned with his plans, to notice anything else. The boy can't help being distracted by the rich boy beside their table. Genius filmmaking by by De Sica.

reviews.review_title: Four currents of thought in The Bicycle Thief
reviews.content: Examining the film through the lens of what was happening socially and politically in Italy during the years of Neo-Realism gives one many insights into what the film was trying to convey to audiences of the time, as well as today. There are many timeless issues and emotions, people being people at all times and places, that occur in this film. Therefor it's important to keep in mind four currents of thought, that have previously been identified, in post-war Italian intellectual life: Marxism, existentialism, sociology and psychoanalysis. The Marxism, as seen as a socialist societal commentary, is evident in the very nature of the story: class differences, poverty and unemployment. Existentialism is seemingly rife in the film, every scene commands the viewer to witness the deep meaning in everything that the characters undergo. Sociologically, this film is an interesting look into the social structures of the times and place in which it was made. Finally, the psychoanalysis rampant throughout. The turmoil, inducing neuroses, almost psychoses, in the lead character as he hunts frantically for the restoration of his dignity, his bicycle.

A film that not only is a masterpiece in drama and tragedy but also leaves wondering what would you do if you were there?We see a post world war 2 era through the eyes of Antonio who is jobless and desperately looking for work. He gets job to paste advertisement posters but is mandatorily required to have a bicycle which he can not afford.His wife then sells some clothes enough to buy a second hand bicycle.He plans to work on extra shifts to earn and save for his family and does so until one day his bike is stolen!This embarks a dramatic and emotional journey of a father and his son to find their bicycle. But it turns out they find their place in the society.Vittorio's direction is to date considered the best know work of neo realism. It is so natural and realistic. We fee a part of the world.The performances especially by The Child actor were mind blowing.In oerticular there is a scene where they both go to a restaurant to eat and forget about all worries.
They are hit by the fact that despite sitting in the same place as that of higher class people, they can never be at their level and get the same Respect.Towards the end when situational tragedies crushes the fathers soul, he must now decide weather of not to become a thief himself.Throughout the film we know exactly what the characters are experiencing because of the ambience created around is so believable that we get transported to that world frame by frame.This is a must watch for all cinema lovers and professionals.

reviews.review_title: Beautiful story, arresting images, powerful score
reviews.content: A beautiful movie.Plenty has been said about the thematic nuances and brilliant acting, and these are stupendous.I also want to highlight how much I enjoyed the technical execution. There are a number of images which are absolutely arresting: the shot of Bruno atop the stairs next to the bridge, the shot moments before Ricci steals the bicycle, the entire scene as the pair stand beneath the awning next to the plaza to avoid the rain...Also wonderful is the music. Simple, repeated, but with development and variation when necessary, just like the narrative.The final several minutes see this all culminate in one of the most wrenching finales of a movie I've ever seen, capping off what I feel is safe to call a masterpiece.

SPOILER!! Disappointment, hardship, and in the end desperation are the reoccurring concept in The Bicycle Thief.  All of these concepts go right along with the Italian Neorealism movement.  The movie starts out with a shot of a crowd of people begging for a job.  There are only three jobs given out that day and one goes to the main character.  The first problem arises when the job requires you to have a bicycle.  The main character almost turns the job down but relies how badly he needs it.  The only solution that is reached is by the wife of the main character gathering the sheets off all of the beds to sell for money to get a bicycle.  When the Main character goes to sell the sheets you see the extent of the poverty not by just this family, but by all as the camera taking a long shot of the thousands of sheets on the shelfs.  This leads the viewer to think other familys must have to do the same thing to get by and it is very depressing.  The next day is filled with temporary happiness.  The main character goes to work and is excited about the next day.    The next day you are reminded of their sad situation when the boy rides on his father's bike to work at a gas station.  This would be unheard of to have a boy working when he is so young.  The father then starts to put up posters.  It is his first day and you see him struggling to get the hang of it.  As the main character is working hard his bicycle is stolen.  He try's to chase him in the hopes to catch him but loses the thief. The main character then goes home and cannot face is wife to tell her.  When she comes and finds him to find out she starts to cry.  The next day the main character and the boy leave early to try and find the bicycle before is gets taken apart and sold.   While in the bicycle market the main character sees the thief but the thief once again evades capture.  The thief was seen talking to an old man luckily they do catch up with.  The main character then try's to get the old man to tell where the thief lives. The old man escapes without giving any information up.  Then the main character tells his boy to stay on the bridge.  There then are screams that a boy is drowning and the main character and viewer thinks it is his boy. Relieved that the boy is not dead they go and eat.  As they eat discussing as the main character dose often in the film how great of a job he had and how much money he would have been making.  Making the viewer feel worse about the bicycle being stolen.  After that they are walking and run in to the thief. The viewer is filled with happiness that the poor man might get his bicycle back and keep his job.  The thief denies the charges and because the man can produce no witnesses to the crime the thief is left without charges and the bicycle is not recovered.  Not only is the bicycle recovered he is almost beaten up for almost getting the thief in trouble.  If it was not for the boy who ran and got a police officer just in time the main character would have been beaten and have his wallet stolen.  With almost all hopes lost for the recovery of the bicycle the main character walks aimlessly around in despair. Then the main character comes a cross what he needs a bicycle sitting all alone up next to a wall.   The main character is being torn apart in side as the camera gives long shots at the bicycle leaning up by the wall.  Finally the main character decides he needs the bicycle to badly and tells the boy to take a cable car to another street and stay there. The boy knowing what his father is going to do dose not get on the cable car. When the main character try's to steal the bicycle he is seen and chased down by a mob of men.  They catch him and start looking for a police officer to throw the man in jail.  The only thing that saves the main character is once again is his boy coming to the rescue yelling for his father.  The man then decides not to press charges because of the boy and lets them go. The movie then ends without you knowing if the man finds his bicycle, loses his job, or the reaction of his wife.  All you do see is the son grabbing his father's hand to show his love and forgiveness.

In this remarkable 1947 drama, many aspects and underlining themes become apparent.  Taking place during Italy's devastating post World War 2 depression, De Sica uses the real-life environment in the streets of Rome to present his story.  The strong connection of the father to son is very apparent and key during the whole presentation.  During the voyage together to find the bicycle, the wandering pair walks through everyday crazy life painting a quiet innocent picture of father and son.  In another particular movie, we see the connection of father in son in Life Is Beautiful.  In the concentration camps, Roberto Benigni makes the horrible experience into a game for his son.  The connection between father and son holds true during this experience portraying the innocence like The Bicycle Thief.  This landmark film helped identify the Italian neorealist approach showing real life details, detailed imagery, and everyday life.  Italian neorealist cinema was a huge movement that grew out of a political movement after World War 2, following fascist rule.  Jobs were very hard to come by and the economy was very poor revealed as the film unfolded.  Taking place in the heart of this movement gives the audience a great visual to understand and appreciate the tale.  The use of a particular object was used very distinctly throughout the course of the film.  When the bicycle became apparent on screen, the father's heart was touched shown by his actions and facial expressions.  While cleaning the bicycle the morning before work, his son smiles with joy as the sun pours into the room.  When walking around, he carries the bicycle like a fragile new born child. After his bicycle was stolen, his heart was broken acting depressed like he lost a dear friend. His sadness and anger took a path which led him to the conclusion of the film.  Since these times in Italy were horrendous, the bicycle became a valuable object and friend to the father.  Overall, this story is simple, persuasive, and very powerful.  The father to son connection painted a true family bond.  The use of the bicycle controlled the father's feelings and state of mind.  The poetic film style shown through the Italian neorealist movement makes this epic complete.

There's a scene early on in Bicycle Thieves, where Ricci's wife go to see a lady who tells fortunes. When Ricci find's out what his wife is doing he goes up to see her, leaving his bicycle in the doorway and asking a young boy to watch it. My immediate reaction upon seeing this was that the bicycle would be stolen here, I thought to myself, "how predictable". But then, as Ricci and his wife walk back down the stairway and the doorway comes back into the frame, I see that the bicycle is still there. Then it dawned on me: The only reason I thought the bike might get stolen in the first place was because of the film's title, De Sicca had used the title of his film to make the scene suspenseful! It was at that moment that the film had me hooked.The brilliance of Bicycle Thieves lies in its simple yet effective story. Following the precepts of Italian neorealist movement, began by Roberto Rossellini, De Sicca filmed it on location and used only untrained actors. The realistic tone of the film helps to ground it and make it more relatable. This is not a story about superhuman heroics,it doesn't feature any crime lords, fairy tale lands, or over the top violence. It's simply a story about a man who needs a bicycle to support his family and loses it. Yet it's so compelling. That's the power of cinema, and that's why I love Bicycle Thieves.

Its just a simple story, with a simple point. this is one of my favorite classic movie!

Bicycle Thieves is a truly amazing piece of cinema. De Sica's neorealism style shines as he gives extras multiple actions and lines of dialogue creating a full fledged and believable world throughout the film. The two actors who carry the film, Lamberto Maggiorani as the film's protagonist Antonio Ricci and Enzo Staiola as As Antonio's son, Bruno are phenomenal performances.
Staiola is intentionally not a professional actor to give a realism to his character which the film pulls off quite well. Almost every scene in the film revolves around these two characters in some form or another making these two characters' relationship the lifeline of the film as it slowly unfolds, and crumbles slightly with a truly tragic ending.
The film attacks post World War II in a way that does not feel of its time but rather something that can be looked at again even in a modern lense and still be learned from. Every shot in Bicycle Thieves shows the pain and suffering of the working class. It's cinematography is breathtaking as the film uses the camera to truly allow the viewer a look inside of its characters experience in a desperate search for their stolen bicycle that the Riccis need to make a living.

Err, if you enjoy foreign, poorly subtitled, black-and-white films, then this movie is for you.For the rest of us who really need to know which actor said "I thought it was you!", then maybe this is a movie to skip.The story itself could have been told by my 13-year-old cousin Melba in about 5 minutes.However, if you like to see the 'human' side of stories, you will probably enjoy this film, if you can stay awake.

reviews.review_title: A Perfect Example of Italian Realism
reviews.content: A bicycle thief is a great example of what showing people what they want will give you. They could not have planned a better tie for this movie to come out. It is a perfect snapshot of what Italy was going for in the 40's.A man loses his bike. He loses his good paying job because he can't get to work. He also has to take care of a kid. All very real things that could happen to anyone. It could almost be in the mystery category because of how they have the script. He has the bike stolen and they spend the entire movie trying to get it back. They (him and his kid) go and ask people and he almost fights someone to get his lively hood, his bike back. The fact that he goes that far and is ready to fight people shows some real stuff. It truly shows the emotion because if he is like anyone else most of the people are lovers in the world. Not fighters.

reviews.review_title: Post war situation and its impact on a common man has been filmed in "Bicycle thieves "in such a way that that could never be presented better than this
reviews.content:
"Bicycle thieves "significantly the title reveals itself that its not just one thief but a community of thieves is getting active because of post WW-II effect.
Hats off to the director Victoria that he didn't take enough time to show the poverty and unemployment of Italians in just a 10mm lens.Begins with a crowd searching for a job before employment exchange office,Ricci the lucky guy gets a job of sticking posters in the city ,but with a condition of having a bicycle must.Here the the protagonist Ricci starts the journey and during this how he manages to get his mortgaged bike really just enough to melts audience heart.
When it seems the life of Racci is returning to platform he got heartbroken watching his Bicycle stolen from lower of his nose.The director has aslo perfectly given a lime light to the blind belief in the society,which turns religion to a business.The bond among the family, especially the emotional bond of Racci and his Son Burn is another star point of the movie, which never let your eyelids wink.
A whole day journey of a father and son to get their stolen bicycle and during this the up and down emotions ll definitely leave you speechless.

reviews.review_title: It is one of the finest films ever made and a must for anyone.
reviews.content: 4,75 / 5 - This is cinema. Bicycle Thief is probably the best report on the hardship and despair that Europeans, in this case Italians, went through after all death and destruction caused by the WWII. The grainy black and white photography is heartbreaking and the many amateur actors just adds to the truthiness. It was a big surprise to know that the main part is played by an amateur actor, maybe that is why the film hits its mark so well and comes across so realistically. The big question raised on the film is how far misery, hunger, poverty and inequality will push you apart from honor and dignity. Will the father be able to maintain his honor and role as a inspirational role for his son on such an extreme situation?The film is intense from start to end and it will keep you on edge of your seat through the more intense moments. This is a huge counterpoint to what Hollywood was producing at the same period of time. It is an honest portrait of the struggle for life and self-respect.

This is not a film you think too much about, it's a film that makes you feel. Though, a few things can be said about how it makes you feel. The story is very simple; a man living in poverty during post-war Italy gets a job hanging up posters. For this he needs a bicycle, something that in itself is a big investment for his family due to their economic situation. Unfortunately his bike is stolen on his first day. This leads to several smaller incidents where the man in his son walks around in the city to search for the bike and the thief who stole it. What makes this film is its simplicity. It's concentrated depiction of a hopeless situation. This is one of those films that will really make you feel the desperation of our protagonists. It's empathetic and gives a certain insight of humans situated in a desperate setting.

I wouldn't call this just a cinema. It's a cinema with a wider views. Not only the character of the movie has strong presence on the screen but the environment has powerful presence on the screen. The story belongs to Italy or in 1950s but the sense, the human stress and emotions are universal. There's a deep meaning of each scene. I follow the straight line of each frame. The technical aspect of the cinema is enthralling for the good eyes.

Classic Film. The film relevantly alternates between social commentary and family drama, through a powerful depiction of the solidarity that could only prevail within the family in these times. The wife, Maria, without hesitation strips the sheets from the marital bed : they would replace the bicycle in the pawn shop. The never ending shot of the man climbing the ladder full of other used sheets, is a strong reminder of the hardship endured in these days where even sheets were secondary. In another interesting scene, Ricci waits for Maria who visits a Wise Woman. Impatiently enthusiastic, he joins her upstairs while asking two kids to watch the bicycle. Maria came to pay for the prediction that Ricci would get a job, but he prevents her from 'wasting her money', as a practical man. However, when you measure the length of the human queue that visits the Wise woman, you understand how far from practicality people could be pushed by despair, while superstition was the only guidance one could seek. Ricci didn't need that, he had a job. On many levels, the scene is interesting, as we wonder if Ricci's intervention could have foreshadowed the theft, expecting from the title and the misleading cheerful mood, that the bicycle would be stolen when he'll come downstairs. But this would have been too predictable.The following day, Ricci rides his bicycle, carrying a ladder. Every time we get to see him on a bicycle, there's a sensation of freedom, driven by an exhilarating fast motion. But fate chose Ricci as the unfortunate victim of a meticulously set-up stealing. We only have a quick glance on the thief, but Ricci's reaction sweeps it off, and sets up the dramatic element that will never desert the film. Ricci knows what this terrible loss means. He comes back by bus, ignoring the queue, and peoples' protests. The next day, starts a long quest for the stolen bicycle with Ricci and his son, Bruno, a plucky funny-looking little boy, who makes the duo look like a dramatic reminiscence of Chaplin and his Kid, with a new father-and-son dimension that will be the heart of the film.

reviews.review_title: A Film More Relevant Than Ever
reviews.content:
Vittorio De Sica's Bicycle Thieves is the classic motion picture from the Italian neorealism movement in film, better known as Italy's Golden Age. This is a period after World War II where Italian filmmakers would cast non-professional actors and focus on stories of everyday people who struggle economically, face oppression, and the citizens' changing their outlook on life after the war. Other filmmakers from this era include Roberto Rossellini and Federico Fellini. In 1952, Bicycle Thieves topped Sight & Sound's list of the greatest movies ever which was only four years after its theatrical release. The film has influenced several filmmakers like Martin Scorsese, Woody Allen, Robert Altman, Spike Lee, and Satyajit Ray. The film centers on Antonio Ricci, played magnificently by Lamberto Maggiorani. He is the husband of Maria Ricci (Lianella Carell) and the father of two children. Maria purchases a bicycle for Antonio because it is required for him to have a two-wheeler for his job displaying advertising posters. When at work, a thief steals Antonio's cycle, leading him and his son, Bruno (Enzo Staiola), on a search to find the bicycle. At the end of the film, Antonio is unable to find his bike and endeavors to steal another bicycle but is caught by a crowd of bystanders, making him a bicycle thief. The movie is directed masterfully. All of the actors and actresses give realistic performances that resemble their reality. I love how De Sica made the picture in real locations in Italy, showing the authenticity and brutality of post-World War II Italy. Bicycle Thieves is beautifully-shot by cinematographer Carlo Montuori and has some of the best editing I have ever seen by Eraldo Da Roma. The movie has the famous transitional wipe editing that would be highly influential in films like Seven Samurai and Star Wars.
 Released in 1948, Bicycle Thieves has a more relevant feel than ever before. It is a movie that can relate to people who are striving to find a profession in their economy. Maybe the thief stole Antonio's cycle because he had to use one for his career. It's possible the robber had a bike stolen from another crook, thus creating a cycle of bicycle thieves. Bicycle Thieves has a powerful theme: everyone is giving it their best shot to make a living, and sometimes that can mean bringing out the worst in who they are. Two of my favorite lines from the film are "There's a cure for everything except death," and "Why should I kill myself worrying when I'll end up just as dead."
 After viewing the film, I thought to myself, "This is the best film I've ever seen, it's a masterpiece." This movie will be watched by both film fans and filmmakers for the rest of history.
A+

On many levels, the scene is interesting, as we wonder if Ricci's intervention could have foreshadowed the theft, expecting from the title and the misleading cheerful mood, that the bicycle would be stolen when he'll come downstairs. But this would have been too predictable.The following day, Ricci rides his bicycle, carrying a ladder. Every time we get to see him on a bicycle, there's a sensation of freedom, driven by an exhilarating fast motion. But fate chose Ricci as the unfortunate victim of a meticulously set-up stealing. We only have a quick glance on the thief, but Ricci's reaction sweeps it off, and sets up the dramatic element that will never desert the film. Ricci knows what this terrible loss means. He comes back by bus, ignoring the queue, and peoples' protests. The next day, starts a long quest for the stolen bicycle with Ricci and his son, Bruno, a plucky funny-looking little boy, who makes the duo look like a dramatic reminiscence of Chaplin and his Kid, with a new father-and-son dimension that will be the heart of the film.

The lead in the film is played by Lamberto Maggiorani who seems to be a very good actor. He is not an actor, however, and maybe this is why the film hits its mark so well and comes across so realistically. Maggiorani is of this difficult world and his brooding face is a clear indication of this. His job is to plaster film posters up on the walls of buildings all over Rome. He even hangs a picture that symbolizes the absolute opposite of the misery surrounding him. Rita Hayworth from GILDA is on the walls all over the city, a sign of joy to some, a representation of their own lowly status to others.When the bicycle is actually stolen, the "title" character is sought after by Maggiorani and his young son (Enzo Staiola), a little kid with so much acting ability, you swear this must be a documentary. A grueling search throughout Rome has the essential parts of the movie, because we see up close the actual people and places the neo-realist film movement came to represent. It is a small, sad world they live in and the bike has to be found so that they can live. The father is put to the ultimate test in front of his son. Will he do the honorable thing or will he do what his mind and heart know is only possible? These are the tense moments of the film's climax.

reviews.content: A simple sad story of reality in poverty. A balance depiction of the cases of poor and rich. Most scenes are kinda boring.

Powerful Italian film - post-war. The story is simple, as it often is for the greatest films. It's about a man named Ricci, who just got a job in a post-War unemployment-stricken Roma. The community's hopelessness weakened its fraternal spirit as illustrated by these human queues protesting when only one's got a job. And that day seems to be Ricci's day : he will start working as a hanger-poster, all he needs is a bicycle. Having just pawned his, Ricci's reaction quickly betrays him, but from the crowd's opportunistic cries, he realizes he'd better shut his mouth and do the best to get his bicycle back. The film relevantly alternates between social commentary and family drama, through a powerful depiction of the solidarity that could only prevail within the family in these times. The wife, Maria, without hesitation strips the sheets from the marital bed : they would replace the bicycle in the pawn shop. The never ending shot of the man climbing the ladder full of other used sheets, is a strong reminder of the hardship endured in these days where even sheets were secondary.In another interesting scene, Ricci waits for Maria who visits a Wise Woman. Impatiently enthusiastic, he joins her upstairs while asking two kids to watch the bicycle. Maria came to pay for the prediction that Ricci would get a job, but he prevents her from 'wasting her money', as a practical man. However, when you measure the length of the human queue that visits the Wise woman, you understand how far from practicality people could be pushed by despair, while superstition was the only guidance one could seek. Ricci didn't need that, he had a job. On many levels, the scene is interesting, as we wonder if Ricci's intervention could have foreshadowed the theft, expecting from the title and the misleading cheerful mood, that the bicycle would be stolen when he'll come downstairs. But this would have been too predictable.The following day, Ricci rides his bicycle, carrying a ladder. Every time we get to see him on a bicycle, there's a sensation of freedom, driven by an exhilarating fast motion. But fate chose Ricci as the unfortunate victim of a meticulously set-up stealing. We only have a quick glance on the thief, but Ricci's reaction sweeps it off, and sets up the dramatic element that will never desert the film. Ricci knows what this terrible loss means. He comes back by bus, ignoring the queue, and peoples' protests. The next day, starts a long quest for the stolen bicycle with Ricci and his son, Bruno, a plucky funny-looking little boy, who makes the duo look like a dramatic reminiscence of Chaplin and his Kid, with a new father-and-son dimension that will be the heart of the film.And in this journey that immortalized the Roma that was just healing its War hounds, queues take a particular significance as an allegory of Ricci's condition: a man isolated in his own despair struggling against a system that makes an outcast of him, or worse, an agitator. In a church, Ricci 'harasses' the only man he previously flashed with the stealer, unluckily frail and old. After a long unsuccessful search, Ricci almost wisely resigns and takes Bruno to the restaurant. For a brief moment, Ricci smiles again and lets Bruno drink a few wine. The restaurant scene represents a pivotal moment when Bruno realizes his personal contrast with the richer kid who can eat spaghetti, and Ricci reconsiders with a mathematical precision how providential and indispensable were the job and the bicycle.Ricci's only chance is superstition, an euphemism for luck. "Find it now, or it'll be lost forever" the Wise Woman implacably says. And in an unpredictable twist, Ricci meets the thief, right after the visit and he's the one, as his defensive reaction shows. Ricci violently gets him off a brothel, with the fierceness of a man who won't let his prey escape. De Sica's direction is masterful as it makes Ricci, following the tragic irony that governed his journey, look like a bully to the people of the neighborhood and the epileptic stroke of the suspected kid made Ricci even more detestable.

reviews.review_title: The greatest neorealistic film ever made
reviews.content:
At the end of the Second World War, Italy was a traumatised country wracked by poverty and political turmoil, and Italian filmmakers responded to these conditions by inventing a new and vital style of filmmaking and that was known as Neorealism. It involved the use of non-professional actors in real-life locations, documentary footage and the result was remarkable because the pain and emotions conveyed were so real.The Bicycle Thief, a 1948 Italian drama film directed by Vittorio De Sica is a milestone of post-war cinema set in Italy where poverty is a dire reality for a large portion of the population. Work is scarce, and the opportunities for employment is few and far between. It is a remarkable cinema a sublimely understated yet rivetingly moving account of a young man's battle against poverty."The Bicycle Thief" is about an economically distraught man "Antonio Ricci" (Lamberto Maggiorani) who hunts the job lines day after day to provide for his wife and two children, but suddenly his name is called for a well-paying city job. The only catch is that he needs a bicycle for the job, and he has just pawned his bicycle to feed his family. Thus begins 'The Bicycle Thief', Vittorio de Sica's gritty study in realism. Ricci and his wife sells their bedsheets to get the bicycle back, only to have the bicycle stolen on his first day at the job and when they go to the police for help, they ignore him believing the bicycle is not as important as it is. Thus the father and his young son take it upon themselves to look all over town to try and find the bicycle to keep the job. Ricci and his young son walk around Rome, desperate to find the thief, and more importantly, the bicycle before his next day of work.
The city Rome also plays a significant role in this film, not the picture-postcard tourist Rome, but a harsh, strange, unsettling place. One of the things Neorealism does and De Sica is brilliant at, is he takes you on a tour of this city and shows in a very simple theme how the society works, for example when Ricci went to the police station for help after his bike was stolen they simply ignored him. The society seems organised almost as a conspiracy to strip its members and particularly its poorest citizens of their very dignity.The story that the "Bicycle Thieves" tells is simple and is one that connects to a lot of people. The story depicts the day to day struggles and the hardship faced by people to make ends meet and survive. The Bicycle Thief' has been a critical favorite for decades for a good reason. It is a must-see film for any cinephile.

Bicycle Thieves bring me back to the postwar Italy, location shooting significantly contributed to the realistic nature of neorealist movies. Actors also showed a great performance. The movie clearly reflects the sorrowful reality of the lower class, the emotion are shared to audience.

reviews.review_title: A simple movie with great deep effects
reviews.content: This movie is amazing in its kind. There are no long talking scenes and, yet it penetrates your heart. It is talking to you with the language of experience, it doesn't need to tell you how the characters feel or what they want to express; you are familiar with the concept and experience that the story wants to share with you. By the way, one day after I watched this movie, someone stoled my bike. (Haha what a coincidence)

The reason this film is so widely praised is due to its simplicity. From the outset you are pulled into post-war Italy, understanding the struggle to secure work and the abject poverty of its citizens. The story of a stolen bike is relatable and yet poignant within the frame of desperation.The adult nature of the young boy reflects a need to grow up fast and take on responsibility in a challenging world. The lack of a clear resolution to the story also leaves a lasting impact

reviews.review_title: Everyone should see this movie (this is my first ever movie review)
reviews.content: The main body of this film follows a man, Ricci, as he is searching for his stolen bicycle in the city of Rome. He does not live in the city. He lives outside of the city where he and his family live in poverty. At the beginning of the film, he is offered a job, but the only way for him to do the job. He is able to obtain the bicycle by pawning off some of his families belongings. Ricci starts his work hanging posters around the city the next day. The bicycle is a sign of hope for this family. Ricci and his family have lived in a cycle of poverty their entire lives. Ricci even says early in the film that he has been cursed since the day he was born. The bicycle appears to be a sign that the curse has been lifted. Well, that actually isn't the case because the very first day on the job the bicycle gets stolen. As he is searching for his bike, he turns to the government (the police) to help him, and it does no good. He also turns to religion (a seer) to help him, and that also does no good. Ricci hits rock bottom and think that his only option is to steal someone else's bicycle. He is that desperate. What choice does he have? His only choice is to take matters into his own hands and the only option that seems possible at the time is to steal someone else's bike. Everything in this movie was very well done. The acting was great. I really liked the little boy who played Ricci's son. The music was very subtle but set the tone for the movie and helped the movie to flow very nicely. It seems to me that the theme of this movie was "things are bad, but they could be a whole lot worse". It also was good at expressing the difficulty of living in poverty.

If there ever was that ONE movie that you had to watch, it undoubtedly has to be this.'Bicycle Thieves' or 'The Bicycle Thief' has a rather simple plot outline, with the protagonist's bicycle stolen on the first day of work. He absolutely needs this bicycle to continue working on his new job, and this leads him to start looking for it all over on the streets of Rome. There is hope all over the film. Hope of finding the bicycle each time he attempts in pursuing one lead or the other.The main essence of this film is relationships. Firstly, it's between the father and mother. The mother is shown to be a delicate young woman, who loves her husband, and is excited when her husband finds a new job. There are scenes in this film which have been shot so well, that you can actually feel this strong bond between the two. Secondly, and shown with more significance, is the relationship between the father and his young 7-8 year old son. There are powerful, heart-wrenching and beautiful scenes all over the movie that are shared by them both. There is not a chance that you would miss them. This film has several themes: Hope, a parent's love and concern, an indifferent world, poverty ...The director, De Sica, was a genius to have hired a totally unprofessional cast to act in this film. The actors played their roles to perfection, even the expressions made by the young son were exactly what was needed to make this film just PERFECT.And which is why I say - Everyone needs to watch this piece of art!
